Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Testing long-standing adaptive hypotheses for floral traits in the UV spectrum using comparative methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant species that vary in flower color are excellent models for understanding the evolutionary processes that maintain variation. However, the insects that are attracted to the flowers and subsequently pollinate them perceive color in the ultraviolet (UV) spectrum, and many plants have UV floral patterns (i.e., variation in the degree of UV reflectance) that go unseen by the naked human eye. The main hypothesis for the evolution of UV flower color is pollinator attraction and efficiency. However, factors like abiotic stress may also impose natural selection. Neither of these hypotheses has been adequately tested, thus we are far from a synthetic view of the evolutionary processes influencing floral patterns as they appear to insects. This project will address this gap using Potentilla, a plant genus highly variable for floral UV pattern, some species have patterned flowers while others are UV-absorptive or reflective. The research will examine the evolutionary relationships within the genus and characterize floral traits and habitat for all species to reveal evolutionary transitions in UV pattern. Further, field-based experiments will test putative biotic and abiotic drivers of UV pattern diversification.

Understanding the evolution of diversity of flower color is important to conservation of biodiversity. In addition, understanding plant pollinator interactions has important practical implications for agriculture. Genetic data on the plants will be made available through public databases. The project includes mentoring several undergraduates in the scientific process as well as graduate student training. The project will also include outreach through the University of Pittsburgh Middle School Outreach Program, including teacher training and classroom participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Doctoral Dissertation Grant Testing long-standing adaptive hypotheses for floral traits in the UV spectrum using comparative methods has generated a number of  advances in our understanding of the ecology and evolution of ultraviolet floral pigmentation. This support has contributed to four manuscripts (three published [Nature Plants, New Phytologist, Ecology], one submitted) that have explored the ecological role of UV pigmentation with respect to pollinators and abiotic stress, at both microevolutionary and macroevolutionary scales. Additional discovery has been made in our understanding of the intrinsic traits of species that determine range size (one manuscript submitted).

Koski and Ashman evaluated how abiotic factors lead to broad scale, global patterns in UV floral variation to learn that UV-B irradiance selects for greater UV pigmentation of flowers in one species. They extended this work the Potentilleae Tribe of plants (Rosaceae), to discover that across many taxa, those occurring at higher altitudes have more UV pigmentation in petals. This corresponds with increased UV irradiance and reduced temperatures, thus abiotic stress can contribute to flower color variation among species. This study contributed to the publicly-available genetic resources for the Potentilleae tribe as it produced a molecular phylogeny of 183 species using nuclear and chloroplast sequences. Using a phylogenetic framework, Koski and Ashman tested hypotheses that sister taxa that grow in sympatry (overlapping ranges) would have greater floral differences than those that occur in allopatry (non-overlapping ranges), a signature of reproductive character displacement. They discovered that UV floral pigmentation was in fact more similar for sympatric sister species, supporting the role of environmental filtering as a mechanism that drives trait differences among species. Koski and Ashman mentored University of Pittsburgh undergraduate, Hayley Brittingham, in independent research aimed at testing whether polyploids, or species with high intraspecific diversity in ploidy, have larger range size. Brittingham found that diploids and polyploids have similar range size, but that species with higher ploidy diversity have larger ranges than those with lower ploidy diversity. This work adds a new dimension to our understanding of plant traits that determine range size and trained Brittingham in independent research and manuscript preparation.

Three undergraduate researchers were either supported directly by the grant or involved in research related to the grant. Koski was their main mentor and was thus trained in advising and management. Koski and Ashman developed pollination biology activities for Pittsburgh area elementary school students, and Koski shared his research at the Cleveland Metroparks Backyard Biodiversity Bash.
